clinical_study.brief_title: Randomized Pilot Study Comparing Two Vacuum-wound-dressings for Open Abdomen Treatment
clinical_study.official_title: Vacuum-Therapy in Open Abdomen Treatment - Randomized Pilot-trial Comparing Fascial Closure and Survival With "Vacuum-Pack"-Technique vs. "Abdominal Dressing"

brief_summary.textblock:
The primary purpose of the study is to determine whether two vacuum-wound-dressing techniques (the so called "abdominal dressing" versus "vacuum-pack-technique") are equally effective in the treatment of open abdomen.
Secondary purpose is the comparison of feasibility and economic aspects.

clinical_study.why_stopped: extended obligations of amended medical device law in Germany 2010 did not allow to continue and complete the trial due to budget limitation

primary_outcome.measure: Failure of delayed abdominal fascial closure (non-prevented ventral hernia) and/or in-hospital-death of any cause (combined primary outcome)
primary_outcome.time_frame: until end of vacuum-therapy or death

secondary_outcome.time_frame: until end of vacuum-therapy or death
until end of vacuum-therapy or death
until end of ICU-therapy or death

secondary_outcome.measure: post-dismissal health-related quality of life (SF36 and EQ-5D questionnaire)
recurrent hernia/abdominal wall dehiscence after initial facial closure during hospital stay

intervention.description: Negative-pressure-wound-therapy applying a method described by Brock, Barker et al 1995: "Temporary Closure of Open Abdominal Wounds - the Vacuum Pack" (see citations).

Negative-pressure-wound-therapy for temporary abdominal closure applying a device of KCI International (V.A.C.® Abdominal Dressing System). see: http://www.kci-medical.com/kci/corporate/kcitherapies/vactherapy/dressings/abdominal/#

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients indicated for open-abdomen-treatment by responsible consultant surgeon where vacuum-technique is judged technically possible
Exclusion Criteria:
- Technical reasons
- unjustified risk-benefit-ratio of manipulations necessary for application of vacuum-pack-technique or abdominal-dressing-technique
